LOCAL NEWS.
Use Clark's Glycerine Cream for beautifying the skin.
Tramway payments in this district commence Tuesday next.
A considerable amount of freight arrived in Prince Albert last week, and innumerable are on their way from Troy loaded with merchandise for our merchants.
Tenders are asked for the erection of a log building for the Collegiate School district. Specifications can be had from the Secretary of the Board, Mr. H. W. Halpin.
Mr. J. M. Campbell, with his usual enterprise, has imported a thoroughbred stallion. He is a good horse, a little over four years old, a beautiful dapple grey, with a star on his forehead, good bone, nice white markings, and very good temper. His action is only one year old.
Mr. Thomas Rodgers, who for some time was the express agent here, has returned from Europe, improved so much that he came back on Thursday last in company with his brother-in-law, Mr. N. R. Rodgers, for whom he has been away for several months. He will soon recover his usual health.
The fire appliances purchased by the town have been placed in the hands of the fire brigade, and the fire brigade thoroughly organized so that in case of need everything will be in its place and everyone knows his duty. It will also be possible to lock up the stable door after the horse has been taken out.
The secretary of the Lorne Agricultural Society will be pleased to receive sample bunches, about three inches thick in the center of width, of barley or wheat. The latter are to be used for sowing purposes. Come, also sending immaculate wares that can be grown here.
We understand that the building of Harris Son & Co., lately used as a store house, will be let by tender. We understand that the same premises will be made available for a grain elevator, and an additional space was put up to hold seed. Some of our enterprising men might take into consideration, and send in their samples for the benefit of the town. Why does not the Agricultural Society secure the use of it for their annual show?

CHIT-CHAT LOCALS.
Gathered by our reporter
B. B. Ritter at Clark's Drug Store.
Judge Macleod and family are expected here shortly.
Mr. Williamson commenced work on the main drain on Tuesday.
Miss Simcoe, mother of Carleton, visited us a day or two this week.
Are you a member of the Lorne Agricultural Society? Only one dollar.
Mr. Wm. Knox was out at the South Branch a few days last week prospecting.
Mr. Fortescue and family, of Athabasca, visited us on their way here from Qu'Appelle.
The Prince Fire Brigade will meet in the Council Chamber on Tuesday next, at 7 p.m.
Mr. E. T. Baker, foreman of the police force, was out on the sick list during the week.
The Carrot River Agricultural Society will hold their second annual exhibition on Saturday next.
Mr. Beatty of Carrot River district was in town this week, and was the guest of Mr. J. M. Campbell.
The Prince Saskatchewan Lottery takes place on Tuesday next, at the residence of Mr. Dan Cameron.
Mr. Duncan Campbell of the east end, brought Mrs. Maclean with him and three little children for dinner, etc.
We are informed upon good authority that Mr. Albert Hudson's father has fallen heir to the balance of about $100,000.
By becoming a member of the Lorne Agricultural Society you assist the Society to secure a larger Government grant.
Mr. Goodfellow is doing the work on the new schoolhouse, and we have now ready for occupation about the first of October.
Mr. Goodfellow has purchased one of the very best organs for their church. This speaks well for the energy of the new pastor Rev. Mr. Howard.
Mr. Edward Johnson, of Qu'Appelle, visited us in a boat of Oregon hones this week. This is the third band brought into Prince Albert this season.
Many will be interested to learn that Mr. Miller lost his pair of imported horses. They were worth at least $600. He also had a fine young stallion, two mares, and a colt.
Mr. H. W. Peters, Government overseer of the police barracks, has received instructions to erect two more buildings, one a hospital and the other a stable for six horses.
The celebrated West Highland terrier, which was bought by Mr. Mitchell at Quebec, has been brought to Prince Albert. His thoroughbred Anglia Polled bull has reached his ranch at Duke Rock.
Mr. Clarke and Mr. John Stewart returned from Winnipeg on Thursday. They were brought in by stage and made the trip in three days without mishap.
Messrs. Andrew and Hugh Nelson have commenced the erection of a house on the hill just east of Mr. Hardy's dwelling, and facing Mr. St. Louis mansion.
Mr. John Stewart is importing a thoroughbred Durham bull and cow, and some Shropshire sheep from the well known breeder, Messrs. J. & R. Baker, of Athabasca. Mr. Stewart is also getting a thoroughbred Durham bull from the same breeders. They are ex excellent specimens of their breed.
The committee appointed by the directors of the Lorne Agricultural Society to select a suitable building for the display of their exhibits, found the most convenient place is Mr. McIlroy's shop on the Hard & Baker block, opposite the post office, and an addition made at the south end and covered with canvas.
For coughs and colds use Clark's syrup of Tar and Wild Cherry, with lime.
The Toronto Telegram says that the headway is being made towards the settlement of the fisheries question by the appointment of a commission. We may say at once that such a commission will not be set until a settlement of the question has been reached. While the commission is about it why should it not be set up to power to take up the question of extraterritorial settlement also? These subjects have been before the people of the two countries long enough. As for the fishermen, there are more fish in the sea than will ever be caught, just as for the Indians there is plenty of land. The only reason for not handling them over to the courts of their own country. A defaulter who came out from his native land, by the sale of so doing furnishes prima facie evidence of his guilt. If he were not guilty he would not need to become a fugitive from justice. Settle the fisheries question, settle the commerce law, and establish close commercial relations between the two countries, and then this talk of annexation will come to an end.

In one of the English magazines Mr. Gladstone makes some calculations of interest to the Liberal party—the object being to show that the country is turning its face more and more towards Liberalism, and that the present reaction is simply a Liberal triumph. Mr. Gladstone is always sanguine. It is this quality that so largely commends him to his followers. If he were not to be convinced by the facts showing that the tide of the picture spread on the bright side they would desert him in shoals, so heavy are the demands he makes upon their loyalty to himself by allying themselves to his cause. Take Irish Bills as an example. These were swallowed by the Liberal party mainly because they were Mr. Gladstone's. Any body else who had made such a proposal the Liberals would have been hooted out of public life. His desire is said to be wind up his career by settling the Irish question. He fails to see that he has laid down, but it is quite evident that at his time of life he cannot expect to live to see the effect of the settlement. Two things the Irish agitation has done—deprived Ireland of her landlord out of the country, and the other to put an end to English rule in Ireland. Is this not rather more than they have a right to expect?

English visitors all speak highly of Canada and her trans-continental railway. They come over expecting to find this a sparsely settled country with a simple state of railways running through it, and the most flourishing cities and railways running in all directions. To most of them, when they take as in with their single eye glass, Canada is a revelation, and they do not hesitate to express their astonishment at the progress the country has made. But why should it not make progress? It is peopled by men and women of hardy growth, who are fond of adventure, in a country which any country must well look forward with hopeful expectation. There is probably no country on earth where the comfort of life are so generally distributed as in the Canadian States. Here are millions of millionaires. We do not need them, and the sentiment expressed by one of themselves the other day that the time will come when it will be a reflection on a man to be very rich will prevail, and the result will be the end most that a good harvest is a matter of vital concern.

The summer has been short but too short most people think. But it must not be assumed that summer is short because of a few cool days. There will be warm weather yet. The finest months in the year of our Canadian climate are still before us. November cannot be more charming than September and October. The reports of the crop prospects are not peculiarly gratifying, except as regards the Northwest, where the crops are reported good. The early frosts have usually managed to arrive in time to do no end of mischief, but this year they have been anticipated. So much depends on the weather, and many farmers have all they can do to make both ends meet, that a good harvest is a matter of vital concern.

TERRITORIAL NEWS

REGINA.

From the Leader, August 29.

A farmer has lost his crop for lack of water. The wheat was planted in June and was still growing when last seen. It was then about three inches high. Mr. H. B. Heydges, vice-President of the Macdonald and North-Western Railway Company, visited the farm from Edmonton where he has been for some months past in connection with railway and colonization matters. Mr. Heydges said that he had been successful in the object of his visit, which was to see the land and find a location for a town site. He has also been engaged in buying up land for the purpose of purchasing lands and establishing a settlement. The company has approved of the Minister of the Interior's plan for the settlement of the land. The company will be careful not to make any settlement until such time as the land can be purchased at a reasonable price. The company will also be careful not to make any settlement until such time as the land can be purchased at a reasonable price.

EDMONTON.

From the Bulletin, August 29.

T. P. Wadsworth, Inspector of Indian agencies, arrived today from Fort Saskatchewan. He has been appointed to the position of Inspector of Indian agencies at Fort Saskatchewan and Edmonton at $12 per day.

The total amount of land in the district is about $40,000. The rate of taxation probably will be about $15 per acre.

GENERAL NEWS

New Westminster, B.C., Sept. 2.—A San Francisco dispatch says: The Cana-
dian Pacific steamer here, large, well-
loaded, consisting of wheat, dry fruit,
wines, etc. Yesterday was the arrival
of the steamer in San Francisco of the steamer "St. John's."

St. John's, N.B., Sept. 4.—All vessels
arriving in the past few days report
heavy storms on the Atlantic. The
Norwegian bark Marquis, from London,
encountered a hurricane on the 30th
ult., during which she carried away a
number of sails and was forced under lars poles. The bark Ireland from Liverpool met tremendous weather,
and was stripped of her sails. The bark
Twilight, from Londonderry, carried
away a number of sails off Seal Island
two weeks ago.

Victoria, B.C., Sept. 2.—The sailing
schooner Pathfinder arrived here noon
having on board 2,377 tons salt. During
the last few days the schooner has
only spoke one vessel, and did not learn
of the seizure of the other schooners
which have arrived to-day. Another
action is expected shortly.

The Pathfinder is the second vessel that
evaded the blockade.

Quebec, Sept. 1.—Premier Macdonald
states that there is actually no govern-
ment acting governor or administrator of the
province in this province, and that
having been unable to take Mr.
Macdonald's place while he is in Europe.

Toronto, Sept. 1.—The death is an-
nounced of Mr. Thomas, Esq., of South Norfolk, popularly known as
the father of the Bag Baby.

Sir John has no intention of visiting
England this year.

Sydney, N.S.W., Sept. 1.—Hon. Mr.
White and party—consisting of Mr.
White and daughter, Judge Boultbee,
D. H. Macdonald, M.P., Mr. Pearce,
Inspector-General—have arrived by private secretary—arrived here to-day
about 1:30 from Battleford. They were
received by Mr. White and Mr. Pearce.

The only obstacle to mar their trip
was a slow, steady rain, which set in
last night and continued all day today
night and part of the day, making the
road very slippery. Mr. White and
his family have for Regatta Day landed on
the train at Edmonton, and will take
the morning train to Calgary and Mr. Mac-
donald down to Victoria.

Toronto, Sept. 1.—It is stated on good
authority that the promoters of the pro-
posed new Conservative paper, Empire,
have decided to abandon the project, and
that further efforts will be made to find a
new owner. It is rumored in journalistic circles
that it is the intention of the promoters
to return to old allegiances at an early
date.

Kingston, Sept. 1.—Two convicts who
escaped in the steamship Jean, from
the penitentiary landed near Oranges
and sank the yacht on the sandy beach.
They were captured and returned toward
the interior of New York state. The
police are in pursuit.

Toronto, Sept. 1.—The militia district
has notified Colonel Macdonald, M.P., that
he has resolved to have the last course
decided upon the disputed accounts
between the militia and the com-
mander of the 6th battalion.

Quebec, Sept. 1.—The French local
paper says that as a result of the battle
of Lachine, the birth of a child with two
heads, three eyes and two mouths.

Sudbury, Sept. 1.—Shipper's saw mill
was destroyed by fire last night. Loss
$10,000; no insurance.

Kingston, Sept. 4.—Alex. Doughearty,
a young convict, succumbed in the dark
at this morning.

Toronto, Sept. 4.—A fifty-mile road
between ten miles southwest of Toronto
and the Wanganui Station, was won
by the Wanderers by 117 points.

Toronto, Sept. 2.—Rev. Dr. Jardine,
Prince Albert, is here in the interest of
the medical academy, to be established
there.

Winnipeg, Sept. 2.—Archbishop Faber
of Montreal will arrive at Winnipeg on
Saturday, and probably be joined by Archishop Tasche for a trip to
Victoria, B.C. They are expected to
return on the 17th inst.

London, Sept. 2.—Chamberlain will
start for America in November. It does
not appear to be definitely settled yet
what member of Chamberlain cabinet
will be on the commission.

New York, Sept. 4.—John Murphy
drove about $8,000 worth of horses Saturday in 2:17. The last record was
made in 3:00. Bonner a few days
ago presented Murphy with the trotter
which holds the record in 2:19, and is
valued at $6,000.

Last week a cowboy on High River
killed two Blackfoot Indians killing
rather than shooting them off. They
refused to go and pulled their guns on
the cowboys, but the latter shot one of
the Indians dead and wounded another. Trouble is feared in conse-
quence, and fifty police, twenty-five of
whom are mounted, are being sent to
realizus to march for the Blackfoot Crossing at a moment's notice.—McLeod (Calgary).

The following in reference to Gabriel
is taken from the Fargo County (Montan-
ta) Argus: "Gabriel Pummett returned
to Lawrence county, where he resides in
the upper country. Whatever his mission
was he has accomplished it. We have
heard it said that he was trying to gather
some followers to make a raid. It is
not to be supposed that he is among
the half-breeds and he cannot make
them off with his herd, and proceed he
can with his herd. He has had enough
money out of the half-breeds to purchase
a herd and a cart and will start soon for
Fort Benton. He expects to join the Wild West show
latter fall. It will be remembered
that Dumas was here last fall, but he did not dare
venture on British soil, so remained at
home. Gabriel Pummett will go along
with him without much work, but
losing prestige among the half-breeds, and,
indeed, a harmless character."

A NORTHWEST MUSEUM.

The Historical Society has done a wise thing in purchasing the Hudson
Bay Company new assembly hall for
reception at its noon, this afternoon.
The museum, especially those whose
roots are situated in the far north and
northwest, will splendid opportunities
for historical missions and specimens
of geological, botanical and ethnological
interest. The members of the society
are acquainted with many facts regard-
ing the history of the Northwest which might
be brought to light through such a
museum and would be of great value
to the students of the subject. The
Hudson Bay factors furnished the institute
with one of its most valuable collections,
especially those relating to the
Northwest. Indeed, the Smithsonian
Institute contains the only complete
collection of Hudson Bay artifacts on
the continent, and Canadians have to
go to Washington to properly study the
subject. The museum will be of great
value to the students of the subject in
the country. The Hudson Bay officers
were without doubt but only too glad
to assist the Historical Society in such an
object instead of sending their appear-
ances to United States museums.

And what a fine record which this
institute has made which will illustrate
more clearly than any other how
Washington collection is simply because
there is nothing in the Northwest which would
appreciate their donations.—Calif.
